There is a risk that you are being asked to make an unauthorised payment.  No matter how small the amount, facilitation payments are illegal in most countries in which we operate and UK law forbids them anywhere in the world.  Even if not deliberate, making facilitation payments can seriously damage our reputation.
You should strongly resist any demand for this kind of payment. Say no and use the following to help you challenge the fee.
Remain calm and be prepared to wait.  Showing impatience can increase pressure to pay.  Use any or all of these statements to help you explain why you won't pay.
Remain courteous, respectful and if possible friendly
Make it clear that your company does not allow you to make irregular, non-standard or unofficial payments of any kind
Ask for name and official title of person asking and any identity number
State that you would need an official receipt if you were to pay the fee
Ask to speak to the supervisor/manager of the person making the demand to discuss why you cant pay
Mention that you will contact the embassy / consulate to discuss / report the issue
Explain that you must call your company first to report the issue and to get permission to pay the fee
Take notes or make mental note of the conversations and the time and place for a later report
Do you feel threatened in any way or are you being coerced into paying?

Giving an unearned reward to influence someone’s behaviour or approving an irregular payment to facilitate business processes is a form of bribery.  It is illegal.  This includes being asked for a fee by a supplier to meet key people or to arrange a meeting.  This is and could be interpreted by others as a bribe.
We do not offer, give or receive bribes or make improper payments, or participate in any kind of corrupt activity, either directly or through any third party.

Engaging in any form of bribery or corruption, even an allegation, can result in criminal proscecution and can seriously damage our reputation and our business relationships and is never acceptable.  We would rather miss out on business than take this risk.
Do not pay.  Take action immediately. Report the situation to your line manager and the legal department.
Record any details of the request (time, date, by whom and how it was asked for).
